This video is so false. The ovaries don’t descend and become testis. They both start out as neutral gonads in an inbetween location. The labia doesn’t seal to become a scrotum. Labia and the vagina only start developing after the body has determined if you are a male or female. It is much better to say we start as neutral or both. We originally had these 2 ducts in us, one called the Müllerian duct the other Wolffian duct. If you are XX the Müllerian ducts will develop into Fallopian tubes, uterus and vagina, the Wolffian duct will regress. If you are XY the Wolffian duct will turn into prostate, vans deferens, etc… and the Müllerian duct will regress. Remnants may remain of each and obviously things may not go to plan leading to intersex people.

Nope, this is wrong.

We all start off sexually indifferent and bipotential; that applies to our gonads, our reproductive ducts, our external genitalia, and our germ cells.

At about 6 to 7 weeks, if the SRY gene is present (it is usually on the Y chromosome), the embryo begins being masculinized. If the SRY gene is not present, then the embryo is not masculinized and takes the default path of becoming female.

At no point do normal, genetically male embryos/fetuses develop rudimentary ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, vagina, labia, or clitoris. All of those female structures develop or differentiate after the bipotential stages of their rudiments, after the stage at which the SRY gene would have operated in a genetically male embryo.

I was born with a birth condition in which the germ cells failed to fully travel though out my body and failed to reach the gonads. Thus my gonads failed to develop as testis. Well to be more accurate the one testis did mature to about half of normal adult size while the other testis remained completely as a fetal gonad. As an adult this testis became malignant with a form of ovarian cancer.
Those germ cells that failed to reach the gonad area became caught in various areas of my body and kept growing until they were surgically removed. They rained in size from. 10-17.5 cm . One of them was malignant while the others were not. One of these germs teratoma took on the appearance of a fetus. It had eyes, skin, bone, some organs and even limbs.
In my youth I was looked sort of female and I’ve always felt as such. But I did marry and despite having hypogonadism we managed to have two children. It took many years to do so but we managed.
It wouldn’t be a surprise to anyone that I have had to deal with gender dysphoria my whole life. I’ve never transitioned but between surges for cancer and the chemotherapy done to me there is very little male left in me.
This is who I am, a intersex person. This isn’t a life style choice I’ve made this is something imposed on me. I’m very comfortable with who I am. My spouse and family loves me for who I am and not because of the body I have.

For the idiots who believe this video is right it's not; simply put [ XX = female] [XY = male] [X = nothing/GenderA - YY = impossible], because men don't possess the necessary reproductive capability to make it Possible.

Humans are born with the precursors for Müllerian ducts (female) and Wolffian ducts (male). If you have a Y chromosome, hormonal action is taken to ensure that the Müllerian ducts are killed off. If no Y chromosome is present, then the Wolffian ducts are killed off.

If you have a Y chromosome, you're male. just because you haven't developed everything yet, it doesn't mean you are a female. this is the sort of misinformation that causes kids to have trouble learning scientific theories in school. the second that the egg is fertilized by a sperm with either an X or Y chromosome, your gender is decided. i'm not getting into details about life choices and transgendered individuals here. i'm speaking biologically only.

I didn't continue biology after 12th standard. There I learned about the chromosome and zygote formation. I had read this before and commented that the single x chromosome that is active at first in males inherited by one of the parent doesn't make it a female in any case because the process is still incomplete and going on no matter when the y chromosome gets activated. For example, you make a drink in which you put both salt and sugar. Now you started making drink by putting salt first and as you were about to put sugar in it, someone interrupted in between and said pause, till this moment this drink is salty and after mixing the sugar it will give the perfect flavor. Then he is wrong in commenting that because till that moment ,it was not the drink yet, it was midway. The first moment of it being the Desired drink will be when the process of mixing both salt and sugar will be taken as a whole, to complete once. The same is the case here.As for the syndrome in which women are born with single x chromosome is an outcome after the completion of process (copying of chromosomes) and being unable to copy the second chromosome due to missing of some required link in DNA code of partner chromosome, the partner chromosome is not copied, so process is completed with single x chromosome in offspring that turns into a genetically special female.(Note here that the process of single x has completed unlike in above male case where process with single x is still incomplete as it has to sound after combining with y as it gets activated later on).

This video overlooks the most interesting part of sexual differentiation! Humans actually start with an embryonic form of both the of male bits (mesonephric duct) and female bits (paramesonephric duct), a pair of bipotential gonands (which either become ovaries or testes), and a cloaca. The Y chromosome does cause production of SRY, which binds to DNA and induces the bipotential gonads to develop into testes instead of ovaries. (Interesting side note: female mice, with XX, that are injected with SRY will differentiate as male!).

The testes, if present, produce AMH and testosterone hormones. The presence of AMH and testosterone cause the mesonephric duct to develop into male bits and the paramesonephric duct to regress into male homologues of female bits. The absence of AMH and testosterone cause the paramesonephric duct to develop into female bits, and the mesonephric duct regresses into female homologues of the male bits.

Males and females share the same bits. They just grow more or less depending on the presence or absence of hormones.

The sex of a human (or other placental mammals) is determined from the very beginning at fertilization. If the zygote is XX, it will be a female, if it's XY, a male. The Y chromosome contains a region called SRY which is the sex determining region, it basically gives the first molecular instruction to the embryo to develop as a male. We are not all female in the womb but everyone can consider themselves whatever they want to be!

This video is flawed, I'll give a legitimate reason however I'm a chemistry person not a biologist so I may not know what I'm talking about. A baby doesn't even have genitals until 3 months long after this 5-6 weeks they're talking about. Also there is no male equivalent for many parts of the female genitalia.
If it were true that phenotype which is completely subjective showed us to be female we would have to have genitals (nope) and those genitals would have to have all the parts to even be considered female in the first place (clit, vagina, womb, ovaries) to which the male would also have analogues.
If the ovaries 'descended' then they would carry the vaginal canal out with them and would not form a penis (trying to turn it inside out or pull them straight down it's impossible for the canal to go the other way).
To make the argument that the canal or ovaries could do this and that the ovaries could turn into entirely different glands (limited eggs to unlimited sperm which are both completely different) would mean that you couldn't consider the before to be female in the first place.

Whether this is true or not, the only question is, who gives a flying fuck?

Wrong.  All human embryos start out with a single X chromosome.  This single X chromosome does not denote that tiny living mass of mush to be female in the sence you are thinking.  No breasts, feminism body traits or a vagina as you know it.  The single X is like a starting foundation by which the other X for female or Y for male gets added from the father to compete the babies DNA.  23 from mom and 23 from dad.  There is never an XX inwhich an X gets dropped for a Y.   If the embryos were left with only the moms set of chromosomes (23) the embryos would not survive so its not really true that we all start off as females is it.  Genetically we all start off with the X but the X alone is not enough to form a whole term birth baby.  This vid is a bit intelligently dishonest in its approach.   Again a single X by its self is not female but instead a basic foundation by which the baby is built.

From the time an egg is fertilized, it is either XY (male) or XX (female). The sex is already determined. 

What is true is that for the initial stages of embryonic development, there are no physical differences between males and females. At a certain point males and females begin to develop differently - that is called sexual dimorphism. This is the reason that male mammals have nipples - because nipples begin to develop on the fetus before sexual dimorphism begins. 

There is no reason to say that this means all embryos are female before they turn male. You could just as easily say that all embryos are male until they turn female. But genetically, all embryos are either one or the other right from the beginning.

One chromosome is a lot of different genes which can be switched on or off individually, no? There's no particular logic as to why the chromosomes are bunched up in the way they are - there isn't some coordinating factor tying them all together by the chromosome. Since throughout female development different genes are clearly switched on or off, we can't say that men moved away from the path of the females, more that both moved away from the same path. "Influence of the X chromosome alone" means nothing which amounts to anything meaningful - they're different genes on the X chromosome doing different stages of the development. If these genes were on a different chromosome, separate to X, then there would be none of this bullshit. It would just be accepted that the two diverge away from one central point.

And before anyone asks, I'm not a misogynist. I just don't think this is good science which can hold under scrutiny.

I spotted an inaccuracy. The testis do not form from descended ovaries as the video has mentioned. The 'cortex' of the gonadal ridge (variant of mesonephros) after 6-7 weeks of life will develop into ovaries in the absence of SRY and the 'medulla' of the gonadal ridge will in fact develop into the testes. The gonads, though their origins are from the same tissue roots, opt completely separate paths. The fallopian tubes develop from mullerian ducts and do not form the spermatic cords.

To everyone who takes this video seriously: Don't, because it's wrong.

This video is factually incorrect. The myth that boys start out as girls and then turn into boys has been around for decades. There are serious logical errors in this video that undermine both its premises, and the conclusion.

---
If you want to see how fetal sexual development ACTUALLY works, watch this interactive presentation from no less a credible source than Nova: http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/body/how-sex-determined.html - You will see that this video makes MANY factual errors from that alone.
---

0:00 - _"Get the book..."
I really hope you didn't put any of the material you used here in a book.

0:05 - "Your life actually began as a female."
Wrong. Males are genetically male since conception. In the womb, they start out as physiologically sexless, then intersex (an undifferentiated state that is neither male nor female), and then around week 10 they begin to develop specifically male physiology. There is never a time when they have only female-specific physiology. They develop some female-specific structures (Mullerian ducts), but females also form male-specific structures (Wolffian ducts) during the same period. The ducts for the "non-selected" sex eventually disintegrate.

0:29 - "At the moment of conception you were, of course, male or female based on your genes."
Which is it? I was male at the moment of conception, and "my life actually began as female" (0:05).

0:34 - "The Y chromosome doesn't kick in right away. In fact, the first 5-6 weeks of embryonic development are attributed to the X chromosome alone"
Misleading and somewhat false. Here is a list of genes on the X chromosome: http://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/chromosome/X/show/Genes

There is one gene on X that produces a protein found both in ovaries and testes, so by definition it's not sex-specific. Additionally, X has two known sex-specific genes, one of which (AR, which produces androgen receptors) is mostly useful to males (and trans-men), and the other of which (ARX) generates a male-specific transcription factor. Wanna know what else is a male-specific transcription factor? That's right - SRY, which is found only on the Y chromosome.

In other words, X HAS MORE TO DO WITH MALE-SPECIFIC BIOLOGY THAN FEMALE. There is a logical fallacy going on here, "denying the antecedent" if I'm not mistaken. They assume the following: "Y=male, X not Y, female not male, therefore X=female." X mostly consists of genetic code used by both sexes - cellular biology, generation of teeth and red blood cells, etc.

1:00 - "The ovaries descend and become the testes, and the labia fuse to create the scrotum."
Wrong. Good example of the "definist fallacy." (That's where you attempt to redefine things in a way favorable to your position.) The gonads, undifferentiated tissue that isn't ovary or testicle, begin to differentiate into one or the other around week 10. Before then, they are bipotential, capable of becoming ovaries or testicles - but they aren't differentiated into either one yet. There is simply no time at which a male develops ovaries. The urogenital groove and sinus will either develop into labia or a scrotum, but like the gonads, they aren't either of those things before differentiation. You may as well refer to an egg as a hatchling.

1:12 - "The skin of the scrotum and penis are zipped up like a zipper"
Right. And if the fetus is female, the urogenital groove and sinus also change shape and take on additional features, so this is a distinction without a difference. Likewise, females develop Wolffian ducts, which can only become a part of the male reproductive system. In the female, they eventually disintegrate. Do we consider females "males" while they have Wolffian ducts?

1:19 - "The male variant of the clitoris"
Wrong. (Another example of the definist fallacy.) The bulbous tissue at the "top" of the urogenital groove is not a clitoris. It's undifferentiated. It has to change shape and migrate before it becomes recognizable as either a clitoris or a glans, and the tissue that surrounds it also changes. Before differentiation, it makes no more sense to call it a "clitoris" than it would to call an infant an adult - perhaps even less, because an infant is at least fully differentiated.

Do you see how they keep making the same mistake over and over? They mistake tissue in an undifferentiated state that is neither specifically male nor female, but in a homologous state somewhere between them, and they think, "oh, that sort of looks female, and I already think we all start as girls (cognitive bias), so it must be so." Well, I looked sort of like a seahorse when I was five weeks in, but I didn't have gills. My undifferentiated gonads may have looked (to them) like ovaries at some point, but they never had follicles, egg cells, or any of the other things that specifically differentiate an ovary from a testicle. The actual relation is "precursor => differentiated", but they think it's "female => female or male".

1:21 - "If the Y chromosome does not become activated for some reason, then the female phenotype, or appearance, will persist in the male."
Right, but misleading. If a female fetus is exposed to enough androgens (from taking various steroids, genetic mutations, etc.) she will take on male characteristics, to the point where she may be mistaken as a genetic male with mild to moderate intersex physiology (intersex people used to be called hermaphrodites, in case you don't know). She may have what looks like a partially-formed penis and testicles. If you give a girl or woman enough androgens, she won't develop male-like genitals, but she will develop male-typical body and cranial hair (sometimes even male pattern baldness), bigger muscles, improved visual processing, and a more relaxed emotional affect than she had with estrogen. In other words, this is another distinction without a difference: Both sexes have code for expressing each others' physiological characteristics.

1:29 - "The nipples form before the activation of the Y chromosome"
Right, but misleading. Females develop Wolffian ducts, which can only become a part of the male reproductive system, during gestation. They degrade later on. They also develop androgen receptors, which are next to useless to them, just like nipples are somewhat to completely useless in a male. Some men find nipples useful for sexual stimulation, which is tied into reproduction; so while they don't produce milk, their sensitivity is biologically useful.

---

I told ASAPScience about this in 2014, and reminded them of it several months later. They haven't responded and the video is still here. Why should this be? People come to them for facts and knowledge and science, but instead they get a cultural myth that's literally wrong. They seem unwilling to stop doing so. If deliberate, this is an abuse of our trust. If not deliberate, it illustrates that they are not performing due diligence on their research. I really wish they would post a correct version of this video. If they want to be taken seriously as presenters of science, they have to admit they're wrong and STOP DOING WHAT THEY'RE WRONG ABOUT. This is expected of anyone in science. Whatever page views, ratings, ad revenues, personal beliefs, etc. are on the table may be relevant to them, but that's their problem - not ours. We don't owe it to them to believe falsehoods for the sake of ad revenue and pageviews. That's not science. It's nonsense.

Folklore and pseudoscience don't belong on a channel purporting to be about science. They REALLY need to do something about this.

So a 1 week old xy fetus is not a boy, simply because his y hasn't been activated yet? Makes sense... not.

The x chromosome is huge compared to the y. The y only covers male-specific things, while the x covers everything. This is why the y is idle for such a long time. Because women are double x, the x needs to have all the data that is necessary to create a woman. Using programming terms, the Y is meant to override certain functions of the X, and that's the full purpose of the Y.

This is why females are more resistant (another X to fall back on) and why they have a greater variety physically. You can see this in the coatings of cats for instance. Cats who are both black and orange can only be female.

So to claim that men were female at some point in time is untrue. The X chromosome doesn't represent the female gender, it represents the human species, as 100% of all humans have a X chromosome. It's the lack of Y that defines the female gender, so a XY with a not-yet activated Y is not a female. He may look the same, but if you study his genes, you'll see the difference.

Male nipples serve no purpose, but they are also not an hindrance, so from the perspective of a programmer, there is no real motivation for overriding the creation of nipples through the Y chromosome, because that would require it to intervene much sooner, and it would also increase it's size drastically. It makes sense for the Y to stop the further development of the nipples and the breast tissue though, and this requires a lot less coding, as this is largely achieved by cutting the estrogen levels, and this is a function that the Y chromosome actually has.

Not that anything said in this video is actually wrong per se, but personally I think that it's misleading to say that being undifferentiated equates to being female. After all sexual identification can be broken down into 4 ways: Chromosomal (whether you have a Y chromosome), Gonadal (the presence of Testicular Differentiation Factor (TDF), the product of the SRY gene and other genes/products of the Y chromosome), Somatic (the development of accessory sex glands and external genitalia), and Psychic sex (the sexuality that your psyche identifies with). Assuming that you are referring to somatic sex, the external genitalia present in the indifferent/undifferentiated stage is not of a female's (Physiology of Indifferent - gential swelling, phallus, urethal slit, and a tail; female - clitoris, labia minora, urthral meatus, vaginal orifice, labia majora, anus). While these might develop into a female genitalia if there are no Y chromosomal factors present, they need further factors present in the X chromosome to develop into female genitalia. To claim that these undifferentiated organs are female is strange. Take a look at the Wolffian Duct which in males develops into the epididymis, seminal vesicles, and vas deferens and atrophies in females, but is present in the undifferentiated stage of a fetus. Would you classify this as a "male" organ since it is not present in females and is used in development of male genitalia? I personally wouldn't. But if you do then would you say that undifferentiated fetus is male? or female with a male developmental organ that will eventually atrophy?  I don't know, I rather just think of it as undifferentiated.

I kind of respectfully disagree with the phrasing of this video. It seems a bit inaccurate to claim we are all "female" and more accurate to say " we were all genderless". After all, men still had a y gene in the beginning and women's second X, the paternal X ( i.e.,that makes us all female)  is initially inactivated. On top of that, the sry gene causes the bipotential gonadal ridge ( i.e, basically a ridge that can be either male or female to develop into the testes or ovaries and create eggs or sperm). Note the default is not eggs or femininity, it goes BOTH ways. So, I think we should just stick to saying in the beginning of life, we were all genderless because it makes more scientific sense, but who am I to argue with a cool headline?......

A foetus can survive with only X chromosomes as in Turner syndrome (45,X) but will not survive with only Y chromosome[as in when the mother's ovum carries nil sex chromosomes and is fertilised by a sperm with Y chromosome, resulting in (O,Y) foetus]

That is impossible since female(mother) only possess one type of gene, (X,X) compared the the male(father) has two types of genes, (X,Y). During meiosis, the mother will only give (X) chromosomes and the father will give two, (X or Y).

So, it is not possible for a male to be born (46, YY). But should meiosis fails to divide completely in the father, resulting in a sperm to carry two Y chromosomes will eventually result in a (47,XYY) male.

Epigeneticists have stated that the SRY gene or the Y-Chromosome is actually evolving faster than the rest of the human genetic code.

In 99% of conceptions, sex is determined at the moment of conception (that is, when the DNA of the sperm which successfully penetrates the ovum meets up with the  ovum's DNA). However, in the remaining 1% of cases, things aren't so clear cut. XX males, XY females, XXY, Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome and a whole bunch more Disorders of Sexual Development. Not forgetting in some cases the body develops along one line but the brain / psyche develops along another. Biology isn't binary!

You're both half right - the testes / ovaries and penis / clitoris both start developing as precursor structures that have the potential to go either way. After a certain point is reached, they usually develop into the female structures unless subjected to the chain of reactions / changes set in motion by SRY; in which case they'll develop into the male structures. Occasionally, they'll remain in the immature state: the individual will have female appearance but will be infertile.

Well, male organs and all other physical characteristics that are influenced by it. But they're all basically modifications of what's in the X chromosome, because there is very little genetic "data" contained in the Y chromosome.

The Y chromosome mainly just forms the male organs. It actually accounts for very little of the overall DNA and physical structure. In fact, because females have two X chromosomes, they have two copies of their entire genetic structure within their DNA while males only have that one copy, plus the "extras" given by the Y chromosome. Are you talking about Klinefelter syndrome or XXY? it occurs during the meiosis  I of Sperm cells. It happens when the XY chromosomes fail to separate and produce an XY sperm. you can't be YY, it's genetically impossible. Females are XX and Males are XY. You get one "letter" from your mother and one "letter" from you father. Since the mother doesn't have a Y chromosome it's impossible for you to get an extra Y. Though it is possible to have an extra X chromosome, so you'll be XXY. It's called Klinefelter syndrome.

Sperm and egg are haploids, which means that they only carry one set of the genetic information required. 

The female egg always has an X chromosome, which leaves it up to the male sperm to determine the sex of the baby. The male sperm will either have an x or a y chromosome, since not all of the sperm is the same. 

Whether or not a male passes a y chromosome is dependent on the sperm that fertilizes the egg. If that sperm has an x chromosome, the baby will be a girl. A Y chromosome? Boy.

A fetus transforms from femaleness to maleness in 3 parts. 1) testicles make anti-mullerian hormone, that makes the mullerian ducts wither away. This is what I read. We all have an inborn tendency to develop into females (XX). That is, a developing human’s gonads at one to two months of gestation become ovaries when left alone. Internal pouches called mullerian ducts gradually become the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper vagina, and externally the labia minora and majora appear; this is default pathway of our bodies.

Goosebumps are a physiological phenomenon inherited from our animal ancestors. The bumps are caused by a contraction of miniature muscles that are attached to each hair, The contraction causes the hair to stand up whenever the body feels cold. In animals with hair coat this rising of hair expands the layer of air that serves as insulation. The thicker the hair layer, the more heat is retained. In us this reaction is useless because we dont have a hair coat, but goosebumps persist nevertheless.

Great video, but just a comment: it is not true that we were all female. Biological gender is not determined until genitals develop. Thus, the term 'female' cannot be used until the Mullerian duct system develops and primordial gonads develop into ovaries. Since male development proceeds from preventing female development (via inhibiting the development of Mullerian duct system), it would be more appropriate to say that "female is the default gender."

Why fetishes? A sexual signal in one gender is no use without a corresponding fetish in the other gender. Eg, breasts in women are a sexual signal being too large simply for the purpose of giving milk. Most men like breasts and at some time in humanity's past women with flat chests were selected out of the gene pool. The decreasing number of men who favoured flat chests fathered daughters more likely to be left on the shelf by breast fetish men who made up more and more of males by that process.
Genetics and environmental factors. You could be genetically coded to be taller, but what you do to your body (for example if you smoke) also affects your growth and height.

Being asexual presents problems in unstable environments. Asexual reproduction would result in a very small gene pool as parents pass on 100% of their genes and if something were to affect the population it would be devastating. Sexual reproduction ensures genetic diversity as each parent contributes 50% of genes to the offspring and an increased chance of survival. Some species switch between the two depending on the environment.

X chromosome is responsible for photopigments n thus color recognition. During fertilization, one X chromosome comes from Mom (who bears XX chromosome) n another (X or Y) comes from Dad (who bears XY chromosome) giving either XX Girl / XY Boy. 
Now,In case of Girl (XX), if any gene in one of the X chromosomes from Mom/Dad is defective - the another X chromosome takes care of color. But In case of Boy (XY),when any gene in the only one X chromosome from Mom/Dad is defective,He becomes color blind

Incorrect. We all start as hermaphrodites. The video implies the embryonic Fallopian tubes become the vas deferens in males but that isn't true. Instead, we are all born with both male and female structures. In females, the Wolffian ducts regress and the Mullerian ducts become the Fallopian tubes. In males: The Wolffian ducts become the vas deferens and the Mullerian ducts regress. "Hormones: The Messengers of Life" by Lawrence Crapo for a good writeup of sex differentiation in embryogenesis.

A developing embryo in the indifferent stage has two types of ducts which responds to hormonal stimulation, Mullerian duct that becomes the female genital system, and the Wolffian duct which develops into male genital system upon exposure to intrauterine testosterone. If an embryo has got 'Y' chromosome it starts producing testosterone which causes the development of a male phenotype and regression of the Mullerian duct. otherwise a female phenotype develops.
